column16:
### Since 2018, DAppNode has been a key software for blockchain infrastructure and a big part of decentralization in Ethereum.

DAppNode is a decentralized infrastructure platform that allows users to easily host their own decentralized applications (dApps) and services. DAppNode makes it easy to host and run various types of blockchain software, such as Ethereum, Bitcoin, IPFS, and others. The platform also provides users with a user-friendly interface to manage and monitor their nodes.

One of the key benefits of using DAppNode is that it enables users to participate in decentralized networks without needing to rely on centralized infrastructure providers, such as cloud hosting providers. This enhances the security and reliability of the network, while also making it more resilient to censorship. DAppNode is an open-source project, which means that anyone can contribute to its development and improvement. The platform is also community-driven, with users collaborating to create and share tools and resources to enhance its functionality.

With the recent Merge and Shapella updates, many solo-stakers across the globe were able to update their validator nodes seamlessly and on time with a user-friendly experience thanks to DAppNode and its great team of developers.

As the DAppNode community keeps growing, and by participating in this grant, we want to have the opportunity of further developing some ideas we‚Äôve been working on for the past few months, such as:

- **Staking Brain development**: DAppNode‚Äôs UI for managing keystores in validators
- **Community Packages Grants**: a fund for being able to incentivize those devs that contribute to DAppNode by putting together client packages for the DAppStore.

[{'questionId': 0, 'question': 'Email Address', 'type': 'email', 'hidden': True, 'encryptedAnswer': {'ciphertext': '9MsnJnbzYimxpMvSg/HPyrhHqDe0evg81lR0HMi6mYpYZaaW1HUUDIMU+AWOWGNi', 'encryptedSymmetricKey': ''}}, {'questionId': 1, 'question': 'Previous project funding sources (VC, grants, token sales, etc)', 'type': 'short-answer', 'hidden': False, 'answer': 'Grants: Gitcoin, Panvala, Giveth, MolochDAO, EF, Ethereum Community Funds, NGI Ledger (EU Grant) & Aragon       Donations: Gnosis'}, {'questionId': 2, 'question': 'Total prior funding for project in USD', 'type': 'number', 'hidden': False, 'answer': '450000'}, {'questionId': 3, 'question': 'Total team size', 'type': 'number', 'hidden': False, 'answer': '6'}, {'questionId': 4, 'question': 'How old is the project? (Months)', 'type': 'number', 'hidden': False, 'answer': '64'}, {'questionId': 5, 'question': 'If you participated in past grant rounds using a different project payout wallet address, please share it here:', 'type': 'address', 'hidden': True, 'encryptedAnswer': {'ciphertext': 'v4969DSCqryfSG8Hr9mvEVnQiH0rNI4u8kk+K0yF75bwqP93HC6mF87/hmCcfRzlPKug4j1h20FSxuP7mD79QQ==', 'encryptedSymmetricKey': ''}}, {'questionId': 6, 'question': 'Profiles or socials of other main team members publicly associated with project', 'type': 'paragraph', 'hidden': False, 'answer': 'Twitter profiles: @pol_lanski @eduadiez'}, {'questionId': 7, 'question': 'Have you read and confirmed your grant abides by the Program General Eligibility Policy? https://gitcoin.notion.site/Gitcoin-Grants-Beta-Round-Eligibility-b7fca9fd3c26450b89ded11caaa6497f', 'type': 'multiple-choice', 'hidden': True, 'answer': 'Yes'}, {'questionId': 8, 'question': 'How does your project fit into the ETH Infra round eligibility criteria?', 'type': 'paragraph', 'hidden': True, 'answer': "DAppNode has been an important part of Ethereum infrastucture since 2018 by allowing non-technical users to run their own nodes and validators.

Because we are in the trenches with our users, solo stakers and home Nod eRunners, we have direct experience with the problems they face. In this quest for better User Experience in the web3 ecosystem, we've created a wealth of Open Source tools that any project can use.

Keymanger API: We coordinated client implementers and stakeholders to standardize the way keys are managed between different pieces of software.
Keymanager UI (https://github.com/dappnode/eth2-keymanager-frontend) - a front-end that uses the Keymanager API (https://ethereum.github.io/keymanager-APIs/) to connect to any validator implementation and web3signer."}, {'questionId': 9, 'question': "If you've participated in past grant rounds, please share any new updates or milestones from the prior months", 'type': 'paragraph', 'hidden': False, 'answer': 'In our last round, we spent the Panvala (PAN) funds with the Dappnode Community Treasury, and funds in other crypto currency in these projects:
"33% will to to fund work on the web3signer + UI adaptation described in this issue
33% will go to fund an update of DAppNode's smart contract repositories to make them simpler, adapted to current needs and cross-chain.
33% will go to research on BUBLS, a cryptographical setup that can bring decentralized validator pools to be a reality in DAppNode, started at the EthLisbon hackaton."

The web3signer is now an integral part of how we manage keys safely within dappnode and allow the users to change Consensus Layer clients without having to manage the keys themselves, a delicate process that can cause Slashings.

The Smart Contracts have been developed, but the situation changed and we are now assessing whether we prefer to move to a zk-rollup.

Finally, the BUBLS research was spun out to a different project, diva (https://divalabs.org/) with. a completely different team. We are glad that our open source work could be used by another team to push for Distributed Validator Technology.'}, {'questionId': 10, 'question': "Anything else you'd like to share about your project, previous work, or other project affiliations? Anything you'd like to add that has not been covered?", 'type': 'paragraph', 'hidden': False, 'answer': "Dappnode has tried to find many ways to financial sustainability, to continue supporting the thousands of users that use our software to manage the more than 3700 self-reported Dappnode validators in Ethereum. 

On one side, some of them have bought the Dappnode Hardware, making a contribution with their payment to the team that also builds the software. Unfortunately this is not enough to maintain the project at the current rate of updates in the sector. 

On the other side, many of you will recall a Governance token named $NODE that got hacked. Dappnode made everyone who was providing LP whole on their ETH and GNO positions and will revive the $NODE token. This token was not sold and contributed negatively to Dappnode's sustainability because of the hack refunds. 

We also have Gnosis to thank because when we did not have any more money to continue funding the project, they jumped in and helped without asking for anything in return. 

Finally, we want to stress that Dappnode doesn't take a cut of any validators running on them and dappnode users are completely self-sovereign!

Our intention is to become sustainable and not to rely on grants, but unfortunately this is not the case as of now. We believe we can find a non-extractive business model that will leverage web3 characteristics to create truly win-win-win situations. 

Our mission is to make running decentralized infrastructure accessible to all, empowering users in one side, and being a positive force for decentralizations for networks in the other side.

Thanks for your help on pushing our team forward while we find new non-extractive business models that can give sustainability to the project! "}, {'questionId': 11, 'question': 'Does 50% of your team reflect the diversity of the community your project serves with a particular emphasis on including women, Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPoC), individuals with disabilities, and members of the LGBTQ+ community?', 'type': 'multiple-choice', 'hidden': True, 'encryptedAnswer': {'ciphertext': 'Q5oToEDLvPDQ3mwau8QY0jcT3cbqNaeS86NU5efNn4Y=', 'encryptedSymmetricKey': ''}}]

column16:
Robust open-source protocols that enable decentralized identity management through streamlined key management abstraction.

Private keys are the primary mean of identifying users within a blockchain system. However, they present a single point of failure. To overcome this issue, we introduce Key Management Abstraction (KMA) a chain-agnostic solution that aims to decentralize key backup-recovery, strengthen security, and enhance identity representation.

Technologies we've developed:

**State-Observing Network**: Providing simultaneously a decentralized and highly parallelizable representation of users' identity and a MixNet for secure secrets communications.

**State-changing authentication schemes**: Permission-less authentication procedure for any public-key infrastructure, completely compatible and further enhanced by Ethereum's account abstraction, multisignatures and threshold signatures.

**Decentralization-driven security**: Security layer with a security level on-par with traditional cryptographic security but only relying on the complexity of large-scale social coordination, information asymmetry, & slowness of trust.

**State-change certificates**: Renewable and chain-agnostic ZK-proofs for private key's that serves to sign transactions, provide proof-of-ownership and asset transfer.

Our approach seeks to produce a: Trustless, fully decentralized (and thus, non-custodial), retroactively-compatible infrastructure to represent user‚Äôs identity securely enough to not introduce vulnerabilities and flexibly enough to provide a session management layer for temporality and revocability.

Read more in our whitepaper:

https://docsend.com/view/dbk48wukd3ivd3ad

Our enhancements:

Strengthened Security: While social recovery depends on a group of trusted individuals, this approach can be susceptible to collusion, coercion, or human error. Dippi's decentralized key management system offers heightened security through extensive social coordination and trust slowness, minimizing the risks associated with malicious activities or compromised keys.

Adaptability: Dippi's state-changing authentication schemes, such as permissionless authentication, multisignatures, and threshold signatures, allow users to manage their keys and identity with greater flexibility and customization.
